intro: Moquilea salzmannii, commonly known as the Salzmann's moquilea, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, woolly leaves and showy, pinkish-white flowers. The plant is well adapted to dry climates, with thick, fleshy stems that store water. It typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in coastal areas. Due to its unique appearance and habitat, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists alike.
